questions.text: Which of the following best describes a mechanism involved in epigenetic changes that lead to heterochromatin formation?

options.label: A
options.text: Histone acetylation and DNA methylation of adenine residues

options.label: B
options.text: Histone deacetylation and methylation in CG islands

questions.correct_answer: B. Histone deacetylation and methylation in CG islands

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the lac operon is/are correct? Lac I is constitutively expressed. Lac Y is responsible for lactose transport into the cell. The structural genes are expressed when the CAP site is free. The ZYA genes are expressed when the operator site is free.

Which of the following statements about cloning vectors is correct? Plasmids can carry DNA inserts up to 10 kilobases in size. Phage vectors can carry DNA inserts up to approximately 50 kilobases. Cosmids are hybrid vectors that combine features of plasmids and phages. Artificial chromosomes are used to clone very large DNA fragments.
questions.explanation:
Vector

Size (Kb)

Features
 

Plasmids

  

<10
  • Small, circular DNA molecules found in Bacteria
  • Commonly used for cloning and expressing small DNA fragments
  • Replicate independently of the bacterial chromosome.
 

Bacteriophages

 

10-20
  • Bacterial viruses with linear DNA genomes
  • Useful for cloning slightly larger DNA fragments
  • Infect bacterial cells to propagate the cloned DNA

Bacterial Artificial

Chromosomes

(BACs)

 

50-250
  • BACs are vectors based on the F-plasmid of E. coli.
  • They can accommodate large DNA inserts
  • Used for constructing genomic libraries

Yeast Artificial

Chromosomes

(YACs)

 

>500
  • YACs are vectors that can accommodate very large DNA inserts, even larger than BACs
  • More prone to chimerism and instability compared to BACs

Cosmids

35 - 50
  • Hybrid vectors combining plasmid and phage features

Viral Vectors

  
  • Derived from viruses that infect mammalian cells
  • Include adenoviral, adenovirus-associated viral (AAV), and retroviral vectors.

questions.text: In their CRISPR-Cas9 experiment with a mammalian cell line, the research team observes the repair of DNA double-strand breaks. Which repair mechanisms are they most likely observing? Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ) Homologous End Joining (HEJ) Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER) Base Excision Repair (BER)
Which of the following is the feature of the ‘M’ phase in the image of the Cell cycle?

options.label: A
options.text: DNA replication occurs to duplicate the genome.

options.label: B
options.text: Chromosomes are highly condensed to facilitate segregation.

options.label: C
options.text: Cell growth and preparation for DNA synthesis take place.

options.label: D
options.text: Proofreading and repair of DNA replication errors are conducted.

questions.correct_answer: B. Chromosomes are highly condensed to facilitate segregation.
questions.explanation:
Phases

Chromosome

State

Features

Gap 1 (G1) Phase

Pre-synthetic phase

  

Uncondensed
  • Cell growth and synthesis of proteins and organelles. (Option C)
  • DNA proofreading and repair.

Synthesis (S) Phase

DNA replication occurs (Option A)

  

Uncondensed
  • Replication of the entire genome and formation of sister chromatids.
  • Increase in the levels of DNA polymerases and other replication enzymes.

Gap 2 (G2) Phase

Post-synthetic or pre-mitotic phase

  

Uncondensed

Final proofreading and repair. (Option D)

Mitosis (M) Phase

Division of the nucleus and cytoplasm to produce two daughter cells.

  

Condensed

(ensure proper

segregation).
  • Chromosome condensation, alignment, and segregation.
  • Cytokinesis, where the cytoplasm divides, resulting in two separate cells.

Interphase

  

The combined phases of G1, S, and G2 are where the cell grows, duplicates its DNA and prepares for division.

Gap 0 (G0) Phase

(Resting phase)

 

Condensed

Permanent or Temporary phase based on Cell type.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presents with a family history of progressive muscle weakness, cognitive decline, and involuntary movements. Genetic testing reveals a specific type of microsatellite instability disorder. Which of the following trinucleotide repeat sequences is most likely associated?
questions.explanation:
Disease

Trinucleotide

Repeats

Mode of Inheritance

Huntington’s Disease

CAG

AD

Myotonic Dystrophy

CTG (Option B)

AD

Fragile X Syndrome

CGG (Option C)

XLD

Friedreich’s Ataxia

GAA (Option D)

AR

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with frequent falls, difficulty climbing stairs, and an unusual way of getting up from the floor. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in a gene associated with a severe muscle disorder. Which of the following statements about the involved gene is true?

options.label: C
options.text: Associated with a condition that primarily affects females

options.label: D
options.text: The Gene’s product is a component of the sarcomere.

questions.correct_answer: B. Largest in the human genome.

questions.text: Satellite DNA has various applications due to its unique repetitive sequences. Which of the following is not an application of satellite DNA?

options.label: B
options.text: Determining genetic susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases

options.label: D
options.text: Studying evolutionary relationships and genetic diversity

questions.correct_answer: B. Determining genetic susceptibility to cardiovascular diseases

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not accurate regarding post-transcriptional modifications of eukaryotic RNA?

options.label: A
options.text: The addition of a poly-A tail at the 3′ end.

options.label: B
options.text: The 5′ capping involves a 5′ to 5′ triphosphate bridge.

options.label: C
options.text: Methylation of the N6 position of adenine.

options.label: D
options.text: Introns are removed, and exons are spliced within the cytoplasm.

questions.correct_answer: D. Introns are removed, and exons are spliced within the cytoplasm.
questions.explanation:
Poly-A Tailing (3′ End)
  • Addition of a poly-A tail (20-250 nucleotides) in the nucleoplasm.
  • Protects mRNA from degradation.

5′ Capping
  • Addition of a 7-methyl guanosine cap at the 5′ end.
  • Involves a 5′ to 5′ triphosphate bridge.
  • Enhances mRNA stability and translation initiation.

Splicing
  • Introns (non-coding regions) are removed, and exons (coding regions) are joined together.
  • This splicing occurs in the nucleus and requires energy.

Methylation
  • Methylation of adenine residues and ribose 2′-hydroxyl groups.
  • Primarily occurs in the cytoplasm for tRNA and rRNA.

questions.text: A researcher aims to clone a large eukaryotic gene fragment (~600 kb) for use in functional genomics studies. Which of the following cloning vectors is the most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.explanation:
Cloning Type

Key Features

Insert Size

Applications

Plasmid-Based Cloning

(Option A)

Small, circular DNA in bacteria, independent replication, antibiotic resistance genes

~10 kb

Gene cloning, bacterial expression

Phage-Based Cloning

(Option B)

Uses bacteriophage (e.g., λ phage), foreign DNA inserted into phage genome

~20 kb

High-efficiency cloning, phage display

Cosmid-Based Cloning

(Option D)

Hybrid of plasmid & phage λ, contains cos sites for efficient packaging

~100-300 kb

Genome sequencing, gene mapping

Yeast Artificial Chromosome (YAC)

Functions as a eukaryotic chromosome, contains centromere & telomere

~100-1000 kb

Cloning large eukaryotic DNA fragments

Mammalian Viral Vectors

Used in gene therapy, adenoviral (DNA-based), retroviral (RNA-based)

Varies

Gene expression in mammalian cells, stable integration

questions.text: In human somatic cells, which of the following statements accurately describes the chromatin and its characteristics?

options.label: B
options.text: Facultative heterochromatin includes the Barr body

options.label: C
options.text: Euchromatin is found in centromeric regions

options.label: D
options.text: Heterochromatin is active and less stained

questions.correct_answer: B. Facultative heterochromatin includes the Barr body

questions.text: In a laboratory setting, E. coli bacteria are cultured in a medium where glucose and lactose is available. To increase the expression of the lac operon, which levels of lactose and cAMP would you expect to be present?
questions.correct_answer: C. High lactose and high cAMP

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is specifically designed to introduce specific genetic modifications, such as gene knock-ins or knock-outs, into the genome of an organism?
Which of the following is true about the significance of technology in the following image?

options.label: A
options.text: Used to study multiple gene expressions simultaneously

options.label: B
options.text: Not used to deciding the course of treatment

options.label: C
options.text: They have been completely replaced by next-generation sequencing.

options.label: D
options.text: Not used in proteomics and genotyping.

questions.correct_answer: A. Used to study multiple gene expressions simultaneously

questions.text: Which of the following vectors is most suitable for cloning large DNA fragments up to 300 kb in size?
questions.explanation:
Vector

Size

Description

Plasmids (Option A)

Up to 10 kb
  • Plasmids are small, circular DNA molecules commonly used in recombinant DNA technology.
  • They are easy to manipulate and introduce into bacterial cells. However, they typically can only accommodate small to medium-sized DNA inserts. They are not suitable for very large DNA fragments.

Bacteriophages

(Option B)

10-20 kb
  • Bacteriophages, particularly lambda phage vectors, are used for cloning DNA fragments.
  • While larger than plasmids, they are still not suitable for very large DNA fragments of 300 kb.

Bacterial Artificial Chromosomes (BACs) (Option C)

50-250 kb
  • BACs are vectors based on the F-plasmid of E. coli.
  • They can accommodate large DNA inserts and are widely used for constructing genomic libraries.

Yeast Artificial Chromosomes (YACs) (Option D)

>500
  • YACs are vectors that can accommodate very large DNA inserts, even larger than BACs.
  • While they can certainly handle 300 kb inserts, they are more prone to chimerism and instability compared to BACs.

questions.text: Which type of blotting technique is used to detect specific RNA sequences within a sample?
questions.explanation:
Types

Target

Features

Southern blotting

(Option A)

DNA sequences

It involves separating DNA fragments by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using labelled probes to identify specific sequences

Northern blotting

(Option B)

RNA sequences

The process is similar to DNA blotting but focuses on RNA.

Western blotting

(Option C)

Proteins

This technique specifically detects and analyses proteins in a complex mixture. It involves separating proteins by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using specific antibodies to detect the proteins.

Eastern blotting

(Option D)

Post-translational modifications

It refers to specialised Western blotting techniques that detect specific post-translational modifications of proteins, such as phosphorylation or glycosylation.

questions.text: Which type of restriction endonuclease creates staggered cuts in the DNA, producing "sticky ends"?
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Type I

Type II

Subunit structure

Complex (3 subunits)

Simple (1-2 subunits)

ATP requirement

Yes

No

Cleavage site

Random, far from recognition site

At or near the recognition site

Recognition sequence

Asymmetric

Usually symmetric

Sticky End

Blunt End

Cuts both the DNA strands at two different sites.

Cuts both the strands at the same site.

Forms two complexes with overhanging ends.

Forms two complexes with blunt ends.

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct sequence of steps in recombinant DNA technology?

options.label: A
options.text: Isolation of DNA → Insertion of recombinant DNA into host → Ligation → Cutting of DNA with restriction enzymes → Selection and screening.

options.label: B
options.text: Cutting of DNA with restriction enzymes → Ligation → Isolation of DNA → Insertion of recombinant DNA into host → Selection and screening.

options.label: C
options.text: Isolation of DNA → Cutting of DNA with restriction enzymes → Ligation → Insertion of recombinant DNA into host → Selection and screening.

options.label: D
options.text: Ligation → Isolation of DNA → Cutting of DNA with restriction enzymes → Insertion of recombinant DNA into host → Selection and screening.

questions.correct_answer: C. Isolation of DNA → Cutting of DNA with restriction enzymes → Ligation → Insertion of recombinant DNA into host → Selection and screening.
